review_title: Great mission with too much behind the scenes nonsense
pros:
People are great—you’ll never find a more dedicated, caring, passionate group of providers, therapists and social workers. There can be some territorial issues, but generally everyone is great.

Mission is wonderful—while there’s a wealth of dysfunction behind the scenes, the frontline care is rewarding to see. Watching kids grow and improve, and an organization that supports them every step of the way was worth while. 

One of the top clinicians in the organization is easily the most compassionate and good-natured provider I’ve ever had the privilege to work with. He’s great at navigating the administrative politics while retaining his passion for clinical care. 

Small organization, so there’s opportunity to flex your muscles and stand out. 

Rich PTO time bank.
cons:
Senior leadership is a mess, and it’s all driven by the CEO who struggles to let people leverage their talent and execute decisions without her input. I’ve seen employees at the officer level driving projects that have been shut down on thr whim of the CEO. She had very little tact for how to approach criticism. While she’s smart and passionate, she’s also brash and rigid. 

HR is a joke. They are there to check boxes, go through the motions of hiring and on-boarding and very little else. I don’t understand how some individuals have skated by in that department being so aloof and ill-equipped to support people. When real people issues arise (bullying, retaliation and harassment) they don’t follow through. 

People stay in their positions for decades, so upward mobility is a challenge. 

Silos are a big issue—you can go months without having a clue what’s going on in other departments and suddenly there’s a new procedure, system or person in a key role that no one thought to share. 

I was personally driven away by a supervisor who is not equipped to be a people manager. This individual is intelligent and capable and knows how to play the game. However, feedback was only doled out when negative or if something was going wrong. This person never took the time to celebrate accomplishments of the team. Every 1on1 seemed to follow this cadence: let my
manager know what I was working on, followed by a list of, “Well, here’s what you did wrong this week.” from my manager. I never felt trusted nor empowered. I constantly felt watched down to when I was coming in or going home. 

“This is always how it’s been done” is the mantra of anyone who has been at the hospital more than 10 years.  

Programs and software are super-antiquated. If anyone brings any ideas to innovate, they are quietly shot down.

Public transit options are very limited....1+ hour train and bus ride if you live in the city. 

Benefits aren’t great. Very expensive premiums on health insurance...even on HMO plans, and a weak retirement option that doesn’t offer a match until after a year.

Too many politics, drama, and a lack of mobility and willingness for change drove me away.
